case_vignette:
A 12-year-old healthy male presents for evaluation of rash on the chest and back ongoing for the past 4 days. Mother reports that she first noticed a larger spot on his right flank, then smaller similar lesions began developing all over the chest and back. She denies any history of eczema for the patient or family history. She denies any new topical products. The rash is not painful or itchy. Mother has tried topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement. Physical examination is remarkable for erythematous pink thin papules and plaqueswith overlying fine thin scale on the back and chest. A larger thin scaly plaque is appreciated on the right flank. A KOH preparation is performed and does not reveal any fungal elements  The patient is a 12-year-old healthy child who presents for evaluation of a rash on the chest and back that has been ongoing for the past 4 days. The parent reports that they first noticed a larger spot on the child's right flank, then smaller similar lesions began developing all over the chest and back. The parent denies any history of eczema for the child or family history. The parent denies any new topical products. The rash is not painful or itchy. The parent has tried topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement. Physical examination is remarkable for erythematous pink thin papules and plaques with overlying fine thin scale on the back and chest. A larger thin scaly plaque is appreciated on the right flank. A KOH preparation is performed and does not reveal any fungal elements. 
Note: I removed the word "mother" and replaced it with "parent" to make the text more inclusive. I also removed the word "male" to make the text more neutral. Let me know if you have any further requests!

The parent has tried topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement. Physical examination is remarkable for erythematous pink thin papules and plaques

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash on my chest and back that's been there for the past 4 days.
Has the rash spread to any other parts of your body?
No, the rash has not spread to other parts of my body; it's only on my chest and back.
Can you describe the appearance of the rash? Is it red, blistered, scaly, or have any other distinct characteristics?
The rash has red, pink thin papules and plaques with a fine, thin scale on both my chest and back. There's also a larger thin scaly plaque on my right flank.
Have you experienced any associated symptoms like itching, pain, or fever along with the rash?
No, the rash is not painful or itchy, and I don't have a fever.
Do you have a personal or family history of skin conditions such as eczema, psoriasis, or anything similar?
No, I don't have a personal or family history of eczema or any similar skin conditions.
Have you started using any new medications, soaps, lotions, or been exposed to any new environments or substances in the past few weeks?
No, I haven't used any new topical products or been exposed to any new environments or substances recently.
Final Diagnosis: Pityriasis Rosea.
